parts.text:
A major chord consists of three notes.
The [MIDI:60@0t-480t:root note]
the [MIDI:64@0t-480t:major third]
and the [MIDI:67@0t-480t:perfect fifth]
When we combine all three together we get a [MIDI:60@0t-480t,64@0t-480t,67@0t-480t:major chord]
This creates the bright sound that defines major chords.

A minor second is a musical interval of one semitone.
[MIDI:60@0t-480t,61@0t-480t:minor second]

A major second is a musical interval of two semitones.
[MIDI:60@0t-480t,62@0t-480t:major second]

A minor third is a musical interval of three semitones.
[MIDI:60@0t-480t,63@0t-480t:minor third]

A major third is a musical interval of four semitones.
[MIDI:60@0t-480t,64@0t-480t:major third]

A perfect fourth is a musical interval of five semitones.
[MIDI:60@0t-480t,65@0t-480t:perfect fourth]

A tritone is a musical interval of six semitones.
[MIDI:60@0t-480t,66@0t-480t:tritone]

A perfect fifth is a musical interval of seven semitones.
[MIDI:60@0t-480t,67@0t-480t:perfect fifth]

A minor sixth is a musical interval of eight semitones.
[MIDI:60@0t-480t,68@0t-480t:minor sixth]

A major sixth is a musical interval of nine semitones.
[MIDI:60@0t-480t,69@0t-480t:major sixth]

A minor seventh is a musical interval of ten semitones.
[MIDI:60@0t-480t,70@0t-480t:minor seventh]

A major seventh is a musical interval of eleven semitones.
[MIDI:60@0t-480t,71@0t-480t:major seventh]

An octave is a musical interval of twelve semitones.
[MIDI:60@0t-480t,72@0t-480t:octave]

A ninth is the second scale degree as an upper extension.
[MIDI:60@0t-480t,74@0t-480t:ninth]

A minor ninth is the flat second scale degree as an upper extension.
[MIDI:60@0t-480t,73@0t-480t:minor ninth]

An eleventh is the fourth scale degree as an upper extension.
[MIDI:60@0t-480t,77@0t-480t:eleventh]

A sharp eleventh is the sharp fourth scale degree as an upper extension.
[MIDI:60@0t-480t,78@0t-480t:sharp eleventh]

A thirteenth is the sixth scale degree as an upper extension.
[MIDI:60@0t-480t,81@0t-480t:thirteenth]

A minor thirteenth is the flat sixth scale degree as an upper extension.
[MIDI:60@0t-480t,80@0t-480t:minor thirteenth]

A 2-5-1 is one of the most common chord progressions in Western music, especially jazz.

Let's look at the scale degrees that each chord is built off.

The [MIDI:62@0t-480t:two chord] built off the second scale degree
The [MIDI:67@0t-480t:five chord] built off the fifth scale degree
And finally the [MIDI:60@0t-480t:one chord] built off the first scale degree

These are the root notes of each chord in this movement.

Now let's make these into chords. Taking the first three chords of Autumn Leaves, we see an example of a 2-5-1:
[MIDI:48@0t-144t,51@144t-72t,55@216t-72t,58@288t-820t,63@360t-72t,67@432t-72t,70@504t-72t,75@576t-547t,58@1152t-576t,79@1440t-144t,80@1584t-144t,48@1728t-273t,51@1728t-273t,53@1728t-273t,57@1728t-273t,74@1728t-273t,78@1728t-273t,81@1728t-273t,57@2016t-273t,74@2088t-72t,84@2088t-72t,74@2160t-144t,82@2160t-144t,46@2304t-1094t,50@2304t-1094t,53@2304t-1094t,57@2304t-1094t,74@2304t-288t,77@2304t-144t,81@2304t-144t,77@2448t-144t,74@2592t-144t,70@2736t-144t,69@2880t-144t,70@3024t-144t,69@3168t-144t,67@3312t-134t:Autumn Leaves 2-5-1]
